summary: Hilbert's paradox of the Grand Hotel is a mathematical paradox named after the German mathematician David Hilbert.
full_text: Hilbert's paradox of the Grand Hotel is a thought experiment which illustrates a counterintuitive property of infinite sets. It is demonstrated that a fully occupied hotel with infinitely many rooms may still accommodate additional guests, even infinitely many of them, and that this process may be repeated infinitely often. The idea was introduced by David Hilbert in a 1924 lecture and was popularized through George Gamow's 1947 book One Two Three... Infinity.
title: Hilbert's paradox of the Grand Hotel
